A cavalry unit moving quickly across the field of fire is not a sensible target for missile units. You may kill a few enemies, but better look instead for a tightly-packed target unit, one at a standstill, or coming head-on towards you.

As the main administrative centre in a [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]region[[/url]], the settlement contains both [[url:/manual/single-player/0046_enc_page_campaign_play_province_trade_finance]]trade[[/url]] and [[url:/manual/single-player/0020_enc_page_campaign_play_military]]military[[/url]] buildings. Settlements are the main consumer of [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]food[[/url]] supplies in a province, so it is vitally important to keep food-production buildings upgraded to avoid shortages.
Cavalry cause extra casualties when first charging in due to the impetus of their attack. A cycle of charge, withdraw, charge causes maximum casualties for minimum losses. Repeat until done.

This army is now in a position to [[url:/manual/single-player/0022_enc_page_campaign_play_military_ambush]]ambush[[/url]] passing enemies. However, be aware that hidden enemies can ambush your own armies in just the same way!

The battle timer shows how much time is left before the battle ends. The attacker must rout or destroy the defender within the time limit or lose the battle. To claim victory the defender has only to keep the attacker at bay, so can still win even if outnumbered.

Lower quality infantry are useful for engaging and holding the enemy in place while you go around their side or rear. However, the lower the troop quality, the less time you have before they break and rout.

There is a port in this [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]region[[/url]] that has not been developed to its full potential. Port upgrades enable the [[url:/manual/single-player/0045_enc_page_campaign_play_province_construction]]construction[[/url]] of bigger and better ships, as well as trade with foreign powers and increased income.

This tab shows all existing buildings in the selected settlement, mouse over them to see what can yet be [[url:/manual/single-player/0045_enc_page_campaign_play_province_construction]]constructed[[/url]]. Right-click on a building to read its description. Left-click on a building to add it to the queue, and left-click again to remove it.

The food production buildings across your territory are not producing enough to supply all your settlements, resulting in food shortages. As a matter of urgency, upgrade them to increase food supply, as persistent hunger will lead to increased discontent.

Light cavalry are an excellent choice for riding down light infantry and skirmishers. They often screen the main enemy force or harry isolated units, so getting rid of them is always a sound tactic, if you can catch them!
Placing cavalry units on your flanks gives you flexibility. They can counter any flanking move or make a move of their own if the way is clear.

You are successfully blockading an enemy port. This does not affect their ability to build new ships or repair existing combat-damaged ships, but all trade income through it will be suspended for the life of the blockade.

This tab enables you to research the [[url:/manual/single-player/0039_enc_page_campaign_play_faction_technology]]technology[[/url]] that will give you an advantage over your [[url:/manual/single-player/0013_enc_page_campaign_play_objectives]]rivals[[/url]]. To begin, simply select the item you wish to research. There are no buildings required in order to do this, although there are some [[url:/manual/single-player/0045_enc_page_campaign_play_province_construction]]buildings[[/url]] that require certain technologies before they can be constructed. Mouse over a technology for a short description, details of effects, and the length of time needed to research it.

The [[url:/manual/single-player/0092c_enc_page_battle_play_interface_radar]]radar map[[/url]] allows an aerial view of the battle detailing the position of your units or ships and those enemies that are visible, and also topography to assist in planning an attack. Orders can also be given from the radar map.
Use this option to officially declare war on another faction. However, do not do so without first considering the consequences.

Guard mode ensures that units fight defensively, try to maintain their formation when attacked and won't pursue the enemy if they run away. It can be toggled on or off by selecting a unit and clicking on the guard mode button.
Light cavalry make excellent bait. You can lure the enemy into ambushes, draw units out of position in their line, or just make them tire themselves out chasing you.

Battle statistics are displayed here, along with the options to [[url:/manual/single-player/0021_enc_page_campaign_play_military_sieges#enc_text_manual_army_attack_capture_occupy]]occupy[[/url]] or [[url:/manual/single-player/0021_enc_page_campaign_play_military_sieges#enc_text_manual_army_attack_capture_loot]]loot[[/url]] if you have captured a settlement.
Enemy trade ships are fair game in times of war. Once the trade route is within your radius of influence, enter raid stance to draw additional income from raiding their trade fleets.
When attacking an enemy with superior missile troops, get into melee combat as quickly as possible.

This option is used to broker military alliances. This allows you to call on an ally to provide assistance when at war, and likewise. Note that a refusal to provide military support when asked will instantly cancel the alliance between you.

Skirmish mode means your skirmishers will try to avoid hand to hand contact with the enemy by retreating to a safe firing distance. Try to keep some melee troops close behind them, so your skirmishers can run back through their lines to safety when threatened.

Maintaining a unit's courage and discipline in the heat of battle is dependent on their morale - a measure of pride and belief in their abilities. This is boosted by training, experience and the presence of an inspirational commander. Morale is weakest when a unit is heavily outnumbered or outmatched by an enemy. You can see their morale state just above their unit flag.
Following a new agreement a trade route has been opened between you and your new trading partner. Guard it well, as your enemies will attempt to raid it, potentially ruining your economy.
The enemy will often try to flank your formation with cavalry, so it's a good idea to have infantry reserves on the ends of your line ready to intercept them.

If a flanking manoeuvre by cavalry is countered, for example by enemy infantry moving to intercept, abort the move but leave them in a threatening position. You will have tied down some of their units for no cost.
Provoke a defending enemy into unwise attacks by enraging them. Light infantry and other skirmishers or missile cavalry are good troops to provoke this response.
When troops are surrounded during hand-to-hand combat, they will fight to the death as they have nowhere left to run! Beware though, as desperate men may also be dangerous men!
Where the enemy are concentrated, prepare a defensive line; where they are strong, avoid them. Attack where they are unprepared.

Control of the camera on the campaign map is simple. Use W to move the camera forward and S to move it backward. A and D strafe sideways. Q and E rotate. Alternatively, hold down the mouse wheel and drag, or move the mouse to the edge of the screen to pull the map in that direction. Use X and Z or the mouse wheel to zoom in closer.

Often the best tactic is to encircle the enemy and shoot them from behind or in the flanks. If they turn or chase you off, their formation will be disrupted, leaving them vulnerable to the attentions of your cavalry.

This panel gives you important information about a particular unit type: number of men, [[url:/manual/single-player/0017_enc_page_campaign_play_military_recruit]]recruitment[[/url]] and upkeep costs, [[url:/manual/single-player/0028_enc_page_campaign_play_military_experience]]experience[[/url]], statistics, unit abilities, and a detailed description.

The mobility and stamina of light cavalry makes them ideally suited to scouting the battlefield. If they stumble into a sticky situation their light mounts should be swift enough to get them clear of danger.

Feigning a rout by sacrificing a unit is a sure way of enticing a defender out of a strong defensive position, or luring an attacker into an ambush. Beware though, a feigned rout can quickly become a real one.
When attacking across a river, try to soften up the enemy on the far bank by bombarding them with missiles first. Once they are weakened, your assault has a better chance of succeeding.

The overall happiness of a population is influenced by a variety of different contributing factors including taxation, [[url:/manual/single-player/0044a_enc_page_campaign_play_province_public_order#enc_text_manual_actions_campaign_construction_culture]]cultural[[/url]] differences and devastation following conquest, food shortages, [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions#enc_text_manual_actions_campaign_slaves]]slaves[[/url]], the presence of entertainment buildings, squalor, and the actions of enemy agents. [[url:/manual/single-player/0044a_enc_page_campaign_play_province_public_order#enc_text_manual_public_order_rebellions]]Rebellion[[/url]] becomes a risk when the people are so unhappy that repression can no longer contain public order.
Use Backspace on your keyboard to stop the movement of your armies, fleets and agents on the campaign map.
When you outnumber the enemy greatly, surround and destroy them utterly. Show no mercy!
Ports, farms and other agricultural buildings increase both income and food supplies across all regions under your control. It is essential to keep them upgraded in order to avoid food shortages.

It is important to preserve the devastating impact a cavalry unit can have. When going into combat with cavalry, always charge the last few yards by double right-clicking on the target. Beware of charging across too great a distance though, it's a tiring business!
Attacking spear-equipped infantry in the flanks is a good way of taking them on with cavalry. You should always avoid charging onto sharp, pointy weapons that can be braced!

This list shows all forces and agents currently fielded by your faction, their available action points, numbers of men, the commanding admiral's name, rank, and loyalty. It can be sorted by each of those headings.
Cavalry are not good at defending a static line. Don't put them in a defensive line unless you're expecting to charge them out. If so, have infantry ready to plug the gap they leave behind.

The penalty for breaking an alliance is greater the longer the agreement has been in place. Trust grows over time, so the higher the esteem your faction is held in, the further it has to fall when things sour.
Lower quality infantry make great targets for the enemy to waste their missiles on. They can protect high value units by drawing fire.

When defending territory it is important to know how far enemy forces are able to [[url:/manual/single-player/0019_enc_page_campaign_play_military_movement]]move[[/url]]. Click on an enemy force to see its potential movement extent. When a force is blocking your path the terrain will be highlighted at the choke point. You must fight it to pass through or find an alternative route.
Attacking long-standing allies will have an effect on how the other factions view your own. They will be cautious when dealing with you in future.
Avoid charging your cavalry onto wooden stakes, as the weight and momentum of your horses mean they will be unlikely to survive the encounter.

This panel shows you the information about a [[url:/manual/single-player/0047_enc_page_campaign_play_characters]]character[[/url]] belonging to your faction. Their name, position on the map, [[url:/manual/single-player/0052_enc_page_campaign_play_characters_traits]]traits[[/url]] and [[url:/manual/single-player/0051_enc_page_campaign_play_characters_skills]]skills[[/url]] relating to their abilities are all listed, along with details of [[url:/manual/single-player/0053_enc_page_campaign_play_characters_ancillaries]]household[[/url]] members or objects.

Controlling the camera on the battlefield is simple. Dragging the mouse to the edge of the screen pulls the map in that direction. Use W to move the camera forward, and S to move it backward. A and D strafe sideways. Use X and Z or the mouse wheel to move the camera up and down, and the + and - buttons to tilt the view up or down.
Outflanking is not the only way to get behind an enemy line. Find a weak spot, focus your missiles on it to weaken them and then punch through with your most offensive troops.
